body:
I was able to run a generic fixture in the NUnit test suite using this command:

```
nunit3-console net-4.5\nunit.framework.tests.dll --where "test==/NUnit.Framework.Internal.GenericTestFixture_Numeric\<T\>/"
```

The double quotes enclose the argument and are dropped before NUnit gets the contents. The right hand side of the expression is a quoted string, using / as the delimiter because the command line would require escaping quotes. The backslashes allow ampersand to appear in the command line.

This indicates that what you want to do is possible with the existing TSL but difficult because command-line escaping and xml escaping have to be combined. It may be easier to use the class, method or name keywords.

After some thought, I'm re-opening this. The necessary command-line escaping is required by the OS in order to pass the proper string to NUnit, so we can't do anything about that. However, it really should not be necessary for the user to do the XML escaping. NUnit should do it.

I was wondering if the explore option could show the escaped name, but I guess this would be different depending on the command shell (bash/PowerShell/windows command line, etc), so it might not really be feasible/sensible for the runner to try to output escaped names.

Maybe even a documentation note on the Test Selection Language page might be enough?

If you mean the xml elements, I don't think so. The use of xml for filtering is an internal implementation detail.

As you say, command-line escaping depends on the OS. A note in the docs is a good idea.

issue.title: Generic Test Fixtures are not getting triggered

milestone.title: 3.0-CTP-8
milestone.description: This release is planned to use the 3.0.1 release of NUnit

repository.name: nunit3-vs-adapter
repository.description: NUnit 3.0 Visual Studio test adapter for use under VS 2012 or later

issue.title: Cannot run tests with '>' in name

milestone.title: 3.0-CTP-8
milestone.description: This release is planned to use the 3.0.1 release of NUnit

repository.name: nunit3-vs-adapter
repository.description: NUnit 3.0 Visual Studio test adapter for use under VS 2012 or later

issue.body:
Adapter cannot run tests if their name contains '>' character (and maybe some more). 
To set such name I used TestCaseAttribute(TestName = "invalid name -> here")
